title: Iraqi forces fire at protesters in Baghdad after PM pledges vague reform
text:
A firefighter is seen at the headquarters of the Islamic Dawa Party which was burnt by the demonstrators during a protest over unemployment, corruption and poor public services, in Najaf, Iraq October 3, 2019. Picture taken October 3, 2019. REUTERS/Abdullah Dhiaa al-Deen

BAGHDAD (Reuters) - Police shot at a small group of protesters in Baghdad on Friday after three deadly days of anti-government unrest and Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi said no “magic solution” was available, pledging vague reform that are unlikely to placate Iraqis.

The Iraqi capital was mostly quiet ahead of Muslim Friday prayers. An ongoing curfew, defied by thousands of demonstrators on Thursday, saw army and special forces deploy around central squares and streets.
description: Police shot at a small group of protesters in Baghdad on Friday after three deadly days of anti-government unrest and Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi said no "magic solution" was available, pledging vague reform that are unlikely to placate Iraqis.
